leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 100] s 100 Interest up to judgment (cf Act No 52 1970, section 94; Act No 9 1973, section 83A; Act No 11 1970, section 39A)

leg:heading.title: Interest up to judgment (cf Act No 52 1970, section 94; Act No 9 1973, section 83A; Act No 11 1970, section 39A)

p.text: In proceedings for the recovery of money (including any debt or damages or the value of any goods), the court may include interest in the amount for which judgment is given, the interest to be calculated at such rate as the court thinks fit:
on the whole or any part of the money, and
for the whole or any part of the period from the time the cause of action arose until the time the judgment takes effect.

In proceedings for the recovery of a debt or damages in which payment of the whole or a part of the debt or damages has been made after the proceedings commenced but before, or without, judgment being given, the court may include interest in the amount for which judgment is given, the interest to be calculated at such rate as the court thinks fit:
on the whole or any part of the money paid, and
for the whole or any part of the period from the time the cause of action arose until the time the money was paid.
This section:
does not authorise the giving of interest on any interest awarded under this section, and
does not authorise the giving of interest on a debt in respect of any period for which interest is payable as of right, whether by virtue of an agreement or otherwise, and
does not authorise the giving of interest in any proceedings for the recovery of money in which the amount claimed is less than such amount as may be prescribed by the uniform rules, and
does not affect the damages recoverable for the dishonour of a bill of exchange.

In any proceedings for damages, the court may not order the payment of interest under this section in respect of the period from when an appropriate settlement sum was offered (or first offered) by the defendant unless the special circumstances of the case warrant the making of such an order.

For the purposes of subsection (4), appropriate settlement sum means a sum offered in settlement of proceedings in which the amount for which judgment is given (including interest accrued up to and including the date of the offer) does not exceed the sum offered by more than 10 per cent.

level.toc-caption: [s 100.5] The discretionary power to award interest — eligible claims

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 100.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100(2).

heading.title: The discretionary power to award interest — eligible claims

p.text: The section applies in “any proceedings for the recovery of any money”: Victorian Workcover Authority v Esso Australia Ltd (2001) 207 CLR 520; 182 ALR 321; [2001] HCA 53; BC200105442 . If moneys are paid after the proceedings have been started, s 100(2) permits interest to be ordered. But the section does not otherwise authorise interest to be ordered on a sum which has already been paid: The Medina Princess [1962] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 17. In some circumstances a claim for a declaration may constitute proceedings within the section: Bloch v Bloch (1981) 180 CLR 390; 37 ALR 55; 55 ALJR 701 at 704 ; In Shoppe Pty Ltd v Smith (1976) 7 ATR 242.

level.toc-caption: [s 100.10] The discretionary power to award interest — nature of the discretion

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 100.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73.
(NSW) Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151M.

heading.title: The discretionary power to award interest — nature of the discretion

p.text: The purpose of the discretion is to permit a successful party to be properly compensated for the practical loss it has suffered: Screenco Pty Ltd v RL Dew Pty Ltd (2003) 58 NSWLR 720 (interest refused on part of damages awarded for the loss of an income earning chattel); Andjelic v Marsland (1996) 186 CLR 20 at 25; 135 ALR 543 ; MBP (SA) Pty Ltd v Gogic (1991) 171 CLR 657 at 663; 98 ALR 193 ; Haines v Bendall (1991) 172 CLR 60 at 66, 72; 99 ALR 385 ; Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd v Callinan (1978) 140 CLR 427 at 432; 21 ALR 375 ; Home Owners Insurance Pty Ltd v Job (1983) 2 ANZ Ins Cas ¶60-535; Bennett v Jones [1977] 2 NSWLR 355 . Accordingly, successful plaintiffs who obtain a money judgment will generally be entitled to an award of interest: Ruby v Marsh (1975) 132 CLR 642 at 644; 6 ALR 385 ; Thompson v Faraonio (1979) 24 ALR 1; 54 ALJR 231 at 232 ; Perri v Flavell (No 2) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Powell JA, 2 August 1995, unreported, BC9505403) (interest granted despite long delay in the hearing of the appeal); Falkner v Bourke (1990) 19 NSWLR 574 at 576B (interest will almost invariably be awarded); Allied London Investments Ltd v Hambro Life Assurance Plc (1985) 50 P & CR 207 at 209; General Tyre & Rubber Co v Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co Ltd [1975] 2 All ER 173 at 192; [1975] 1 WLR 819 at 841 ; BP Exploration Co (Libya) Ltd v Hunt (No 2) [1982] 1 All ER 925; [1979] 1 WLR 783 at 845 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Kelly (1987) 8 NSWLR 131 (interest on damages for defamation); Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Driscoll (1988) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-175; BC8802059 (interest on damages for defamation). Because the award of interest is essentially compensatory, the defendant’s conduct in contesting the proceedings (whether or not reasonable and diligent) does not ordinarily provide a proper basis for either making or refusing an award of interest: London, Chatham & Dover Railway Co v South Eastern Railway Co [1893] AC 429 at 437 ; General Tyre & Rubber Co v Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co Ltd [1975] 2 All ER 173 at 192; [1975] 1 WLR 819 at 841 ; Bennett v Jones [1977] 2 NSWLR 355 at 356 ; Falkner v Bourke (1990) 19 NSWLR 574 . Consistent with the compensatory purpose of the section, interest should not be awarded on a sum awarded by way of exemplary damages: Murray v Commonwealth (1986) 5 NSWLR 83 . The general discretion conferred by the section is, of course, subject to any specific limitations and restrictions imposed by other legislation. One such important limitation is that contained in s 18 of the Civil Liability Act 2002 and s 73 of the Motor Accidents Act 1988. Those sections preclude the award of interest (in proceedings to which each Act applies) on both general damages and on amounts awarded for gratuitous attendant care. (In the latter respect the sections overcome the effect of the decisions in Grincelis v House (2000) 173 ALR 564; 74 ALJR 1247 and Marsland v Andjelic (No 2) (1993) 32 NSWLR 649 at 653; 18 MVR 379; BC9303925 , and returns to the position taken in Settree v Roberts [1982] 1 NSWLR 649 .) Other legislative provisions restrict the award of interest in particular circumstances: eg, s 151M of the Workers Compensation Act 1987 (defendant has not made a reasonable offer of settlement after being provided with sufficient information to assess the claim).

level.toc-caption: [s 100.15] Commencement of proceedings – interest on moneys paid after

heading.title: Commencement of proceedings – interest on moneys paid after

p.text: The section permits interest to be paid on moneys paid after the commencement of proceedings: Victorian Workcover Authority v Esso Australia Ltd (2001) 207 CLR 520; 182 ALR 321; [2001] HCA 53; BC200105442 . But the section does not otherwise authorise interest to be ordered on a sum which has already been paid: The Medina Princess [1962] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 17.
Legislation cited in [s 100.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Bills of Exchange Act 1909 s 62.

Apart from this section, and apart also from the Admiralty jurisdiction (as to which see Screenco Pty Ltd v RL Dew Pty Ltd (2003) 58 NSWLR 720 ; Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd v Commonwealth (1953) 88 CLR 164; 27 ALJR 130; BC5300300 ; Burley v The Texaco Southampton [1981] 2 NSWLR 239 at 249–50) the power to award interest on damages or debts at common law was limited. In Eddowes v Hopkins (1780) 1 Doug KB 376; 99 ER 242 Lord Mansfield had contemplated that while ordinarily, apart from trade usage or special agreement, interest was not payable on book debts, nevertheless it might be awarded in “cases of long delay under vexatious and oppressive circumstances”: see also Arnott v Redfern (1926) 3 Bing 353; 130 ER 549. There were in fact many cases in which interest had been awarded, eg Mountford v Willes (1800) 2 Boss & P 337; 126 ER 1314 (interest on unpaid price of goods sold); Shipley v Hammond (1804) 5 Esp 114; 170 ER 756 (rent); Chalie v Duke of York (1806) 6 Esp 45; 170 ER 826 (goods sold); Craven v Tickell (1789) 1 Ves 60 at 62; 30 ER 230. But a more restrictive approach gradually evolved. Thus, in De Havilland v Bowerbank (1807) 1 Camp 50; 170 ER 872 Lord Ellenborough laid down four limited categories in which interest might be awarded:
where there was a contract for payment on a day certain as on bills of exchange;
where there was an express promise;
where a promise to pay might be inferred from the course of dealing; and
where the money had been actually used and interest made on it.

Then in Page v Newman (1829) 9 B & C 378; 109 ER 140 Lord Tenterden said that interest ought not to be awarded unless it appeared from the face of the instrument that interest was intended to be paid, or unless it be implied from the usage of the trade, as in cases involving mercantile instruments. In London, Chatham & Dover Railway Co v South Eastern Railway Co [1893] AC 429 , the House of Lords affirmed this restrictive rule: see also Marine Board of Launceston v Minister for the Navy (1945) 70 CLR 518 at 525; [1946] ALR 61 ; Norwest Refrigeration Services Pty Ltd v Bain Dawes (WA) Pty Ltd (1984) 157 CLR 149; 55 ALR 509 ; cf Fletcher v Tayleur (1855) 17 CB 21 at 29; 139 ER 973 ; British Columbia Sawmill Co v Nettleship (1868) LR 3 CP 499 at 507; President of India v La Pintada Compania Navigacion SA [1985] AC 104 . The power to award interest was first enlarged by s 28 of the Civil Procedure Act 1833 (UK) (Lord Tenterden’s Act) and a similar provision was included in s 140 of the Common Law Procedure Act 1899 (NSW). See also s 62 of the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 (Cth). This reluctance of the common law to award interest began to be questioned in several cases from TransTrust SPRL v Danubian Trading Co Ltd [1952] 2 QB 297 to President of India v La Pintada Compania Navigacion SA [1985] AC 104 . Finally the High Court, in Hungerfords v Walker (1989) 171 CLR 125; 84 ALR 119 , held that the actions of a plaintiff in being deprived of money as a result of a defendant’s wrong “constituted an integral element of the loss” for which the plaintiff was entitled to be compensated. The damages awarded in that case were assessed at compound interest rates; see also Sempra Metals v Inland Revenue Cmrs [2006] QB 37 (compound interest on repayment of unlawful tax amounts). Since that decision claims for interest as damages have been recognised, but they require a factual investigation of the hypothetical transactions and profits that would have occurred, but for the defendant’s wrong: Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 at 363–4 ; Hexiva Pty Ltd v Lederer (No 2) [2007] NSWSC 49; BC200700491 at [9] .
Legislation cited in [s 100.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 42.14, 42.15.

If an appropriate settlement offer has been rejected by a plaintiff, interest can only be awarded, for the period after the date of the offer, in special circumstances. This expression requires an impressionistic judgment and defies comprehensive definition: Re Norman (1886) 16 QBD 673 at 677 per Lopes LJ. It requires something out of the ordinary, but not something that is unique. Between these two extremes circumstances can be regarded as special if they have some particular aspect of unusualness: Beadle v Director-General of Social Security (1985) 60 ALR 225 at 228 ; No 2 Pitt Street Pty Ltd v Wodonga Rural City Council (1999) 104 LGERA 239; [1999] VSC 133 at [19] and at [21] (circumstances are not special if they are characteristic of the common run of cases). Pursuant to CPA s 100(5) the settlement offer is “appropriate” if the actual judgment amount does not exceed the offer by more than 10%. Even if interest is awarded for the period after an offer has been made, it cannot be taken into account in exercising the costs discretions under UCPR rr 42.14 and 42.15 .

Where damages are recovered for loss which has occurred either continuously, or at various times, between the trial and the date the cause of action arose, any award of interest should take this factor into account: Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd v Callinan (1978) 140 CLR 427 at 432–3; 21 ALR 375; BC7800064 . A convenient rule to apply for assessing interest on damages which accrue progressively over a period of time, is to halve either the rate, the period or the principal amount that would otherwise apply in calculating the interest amount: Metropolitan Meat Industry Board v Williams (1991) 24 NSWLR 54 ; Cullen v Trappell (1980) 146 CLR 1; 29 ALR 1 at 13 ; Riddle v McPherson (1995) 37 NSWLR 338 at 343 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Kelly (1987) 8 NSWLR 131 (interest on damages for defamation — assumed to have accrued between publication and judgment — discussion of judge’s entitlement to “dissect” jury verdict between past and future losses).

level.toc-caption: [s 100.35] Delay in claiming interest or conducting proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 100.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 6.12(7), rr 6.12(6).

heading.title: Delay in claiming interest or conducting proceedings

p.text: An award of interest under s 100 should be specifically claimed in the statement of claim: see UCPR rr 6.12(6) , 6.12(7) ; Pheeney v Doolan [1977] 1 NSWLR 4 ; cf Murphy v Murphy [1963] VR 610 ; Riches v Westminster Bank Ltd [1943] 2 All ER 725 . Interest should not be refused merely for the purpose of penalising delay: Bennett v Jones [1977] 2 NSWLR 355 . And even late amendments may be permitted to raise an interest claim: Heath v Goodwin (1986) 8 NSWLR 478 . In an appropriate case the award of interest may be confined to the period after the claim for interest has been specifically made: Simonius Vischer & Co v Holt & Thompson [1979] 2 NSWLR 322 at 337 ; Anderson’s (Pacific) Trading Co Pty Ltd v Karlander New Guinea Line Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 870 (unexplained delay in service of proceedings).

Generally, the compensatory purpose of the discretion to award interest suggests that mere delay in bringing or prosecuting the proceedings will not usually provide a compelling basis for refusing to award interest. However, the general principle is subject to considerations of overall reasonableness. Protracted delay, particularly where there is a significant difference between court interest rates and prevailing commercial rates of interest, may justify discretionary reduction of either the rate or the period during which interest is awarded: Clarke v Foodland Stores Pty Ltd [1993] 2 VR 382 at 389, 394, 396, 398 ; ICT Pty Ltd v Sea Containers Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1280 at [14]–[19] .

The power to award interest in equity was more extensively recognised than at common law. Interest could be awarded in claims against a defaulting fiduciary (Wallersteiner v Moir (No 2) [1975] QB 373 ; Hermann v Charny [1976] 1 NSWLR 261 at 269, 274 ); where a purchaser entered into possession prior to payment of the purchase price (Birch v Joy (1852) 3 HL Cas 565; 10 ER 222 ; Strahorn v Strahorn (1905) 5 SR (NSW) 382; 28 WN (NSW) 788 ); where a purchaser became entitled to the rents and profits of a property prior to payment of the purchase price (Davies v Littlejohn (1923) 34 CLR 174 at 185 ; Canning v Temby (1906) 3 CLR 419 at 425; Bennett v Stone [1903] 1 Ch 509 at 524 ; Esdaile v Stephenson (1822) 1 Sim & St 122; 57 ER 49; see especially Marsh v Jones (1889) 40 Ch D 563 ); or where money had been extorted by duress or coercion (Nixon v Furphy (1926) 26 SR (NSW) 409 at 412–17; 43 WN 108 ; Re Dawson; Union Fidelity Trustee Co Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd (1966) 84 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 399 ); or where the payment ordered was in the nature of an order for restitution: State Bank of New South Wales Ltd v FCT (1995) 62 FCR 371; 132 ALR 653 (overpayment of sales tax). Generally, interest was awarded at simple interest rates, although compound interest might be ordered against defaulting trustees or fiduciaries: Westdeusche Landesbank v Islington London Borough Council [1995] AC 669; following President of India v La Pintada Compania Navigacion SA [1985] AC 104 at 116 .

The Local Court has no power to award interest where a purchaser of real estate has entered into possession prior to payment of the purchase price on the basis of the rule in Birch v Joy (1852) 3 HL Cas 565; 10 ER 222 , since in so doing the court would be giving effect to an equitable remedy which it has no power to do: Joblin v Carney (1975) 1 BPR 9642 , noted [1976] ACLD 170.

level.toc-caption: [s 100.45] Foreign currency, interest on judgments expressed in

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 100.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100.

heading.title: Foreign currency, interest on judgments expressed in

p.text: Following the decisions of the House of Lords in Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd (No 2) [1977] QB 489; [1976] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 434 and The Despina R [1979] AC 685; [1979] 1 All ER 421 , judgments may be awarded in a foreign currency. Where interest is also claimed pursuant to s 100 , interest will ordinarily be calculated at the rates appropriate to the currency in which the judgment is given: Nishina Trading Co Ltd v Chiyoda Fire & Marine Insurance Co Ltd [1968] 3 All ER 712 at 720; [1968] 1 WLR 1325 ; Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd (No 2) [1977] QB 489 at 495; [1976] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 434 ; Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nurenberg Aktiengesellschaft v Altikar Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 152; (1984) ASC ¶55-357 ; cf The Funabashi [1972] 2 All ER 181 ; Swiss Bank Corp v New South Wales (1993) 33 NSWLR 63 . But there may be circumstances where a different rate is appropriate: Helmsing Schiffahrts GmbH v Malta Drydocks Corp [1977] 2 Loyd’s Rep 444 (plaintiff obliged to borrow in a currency different from that of the judgment).

Interest under the present section cannot properly be awarded on compensation for loss or damage which will be suffered in the future: Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd v Callinan (1978) 140 CLR 427; 21 ALR 375; BC7800064 ; Dawson v Hall (NSWCA, Clarke, Meagher, Handley JJA, 29 July 1994, unreported, BC9402852) (consent to backdating of interest sought to be imposed as a condition of adjournment); Atlas Tiles Ltd v Briers (1978) 144 CLR 202; 21 ALR 129 ; Jefford v Gee [1970] 2 QB 130 at 151 ; Ruby v Marsh (1975) 132 CLR 642 at 652; 6 ALR 385 ; Bennett v Jones [1977] 2 NSWLR 355 at 363 . This principle applies even where the claim is one for compensation under Lord Campbell’s Act: State Government Insurance Offıce (Qld) v Biemann (1983) 154 CLR 159; 49 ALR 247; cf Ruby v Marsh , above. In defamation cases it requires a distinction to be made between past and future loss: Otis Elevators Pty Ltd v Zitis (1986) 5 NSWLR 171 at 204 per McHugh JA) the judge may proceed to dissect the jury's assessment: Vardanega v Concrete & Terrazzo Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 22 October 1979, unreported); McKittrick v Kelloggs (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 28 May 1986, unreported, BC8600987) and Baric v SPF Formwork Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 5 June 1986, unreported, BC8600958).
Legislation cited in [s 100.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 s 137.

Various statutory provisions restrict the award of interest on general damages in particular types of proceedings: Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18 (proceedings involving a wide range of personal injury claims — no interest for non-economic loss or gratuitous services), Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73 (claims arising out of the use of a motor vehicle), Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 s 137 (claims arising out of a motor accident). Where an award of interest is permissible notwithstanding such a statutory limitation, it is necessary to recognise that damages for pain and suffering are typically assessed according to the standards of compensation prevailing at the date of trial. At least in the absence of any statutory limit on the amount that may be recovered, damages so assessed are likely to be higher than if they were assessed at the date of the injury. Accordingly, to award interest on such a judgment at commercial rates for the whole of the period from the date the cause of action arose would provide a degree of double compensation: Bennett v Jones [1977] 2 NSWLR 355 at 380 ; Cookson v Knowles [1977] 1 QB 913 at 921; Bryce v Tapalis (NSWCA, Master Sharpe, 9 December 1988, unreported). An appropriate interest rate to allow in such cases is 4%, subject to the right of a trial judge to adopt a different rate in the circumstances of a particular case: MBP (SA) Pty Ltd v Gogic (1991) 171 CLR 657; 98 ALR 193 ; overruling Cullen v Trappell (1980) 146 CLR 1; 29 ALR 1; BC8000068 . This was accepted as generally appropriate in Doherty v Liverpool District Hospital (1991) 22 NSWLR 284 and Trans Tasman Investments Pty Ltd v Donohoe (NSWCA, Kirby P, Priestley and Handley JJA, 19 March 1991, unreported, BC9102203). Where the award of damages for non-economic loss is subject to a statutory limit, the reasoning in MBP (SA) Pty Ltd v Gogic does not apply and interest may be awarded at the ordinary Supreme Court rates: Marsland v Andjelic (No 2) (1993) 32 NSWLR 649; 18 MVR 379; BC9303925 (a case involving general damages assessed under s 79 of the Motor Accidents Act 1988); Bresmac Pty Ltd v Starr (1992) 29 NSWLR 318 at 333 (workers compensation claim); Alvorac General Engineering Pty Ltd v Arlotta (1993) 29 NSWLR 734 at 747 .
Legislation cited in [s 100.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100(2)(b), s 95.
(CTH) Insurance Contracts Act 1984 s 57, s 57(3).

The discretion conferred by the section does not apply where there is an independent right to obtain interest on the amount claimed: see CPA s 100(2)(b) . In a claim to which the Insurance Contracts Act 1984 applies, interest cannot be awarded under s 95 at a different rate than that prescribed pursuant to s 57(3) of that Act: Fruehauf Finance Corp Pty Ltd v Zurich Australian Insurance Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 735 ; NRMA Insurance Ltd v Tatt (1989) 92 ALR 299 ; Grain Pool of Western Australia v Hankin (1991) 7 SR (WA) 174 ; Manchester Unity Total Care Building Society v MGICA Ltd (1990) 6 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-062. However, there is a distinction between claims brought to recover the policy indemnity and other claims. Section 57 of the Insurance Contracts Act does not limit the interest rate on either claims for damages: Hobartville Stud Pty Ltd v Union Insurance Co Ltd (1991) 25 NSWLR 358 (for loss of use of money as a result of a breach of the policy); or on moneys payable by way of contribution between insurers: Sun Alliance and Royal Insurance Australia Ltd v Switzerland Insurance Australia Ltd (1996) 9 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-353; BC9605479.
Legislation cited in [s 100.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100(3)(a), s 100(3)(b).

CPA s 100(3)(a) prohibits interest being given on any interest amounts included in a judgment under the present section. CPA s 100(3)(b) prohibits the inclusion of interest for periods where the putative judgment creditor has an independent right to interest on the primary judgment amount. That prohibition applies whether the independent right is statutory: Bans Pty Ltd v Ling (1995) 36 NSWLR 435 (interest on unpaid rent — as under s 556 of the Companies (NSW) Code); or a contractual liability as a surety: Degmam Pty Ltd (in liq) v Wright [1983] 2 NSWLR 348 (a defendant guarantor). These two prohibitions indicate that interest included in a judgment amount under the present section should be determined at simple interest rates: see Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale v Islington London Borough Council [1996] NLJR 877; [1996] AC 669; [1996] 2 All ER 961; [1996] 2 WLR 802 . But that restriction does not apply where the judgment amount is really an award of damages, even if those damages have been calculated by reference to interest that plaintiffs may have either paid or, alternatively, forgone: Bushwall Properties Ltd v Vortex Ltd [1975] 2 All ER 214; [1975] 1 WLR 1649 at 1660 (interest allowed on interest paid on borrowed funds). Neither does the prohibition apply to interest awarded as equitable compensation: Thomas v SMP (International) No 6 [2010] NSWSC 1311; BC201008599 at [20]–[24] .

Consistently with the compensatory purpose of the discretion, it may be proper to take into account at least some kinds of interim payments that the plaintiff has already received. For example, workers compensation or social security benefits which the plaintiff has a statutory obligation to repay may justify the refusal of interest: Pheeney v Doolan (No 2) [1977] 1 NSWLR 601 at 611 ; Batchelor v Burke (1981) 35 ALR 15; 55 ALJR 494 ; Haines v Bendall (1991) 172 CLR 60; 99 ALR 385 (workers compensation redemption payment). And certainly interim payments made under s 76E should be taken into account. In contrast, the receipt of payments under an insurance policy does not justify the refusal of a claim for interest: Cousins v Carriers [1971] 2 QB 230 at 242 .

The award of interest is a matter for the judge. A jury has no power to order the payment of interest under the section: Vardanega v Concrete & Terrazzo Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 5 June 1986, unreported, BC8600958).
Legislation cited in [s 100.80] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.12(8).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Sch 5.
(NSW) Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18(4).
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73.
(NSW) Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151M.

The pre-judgment rates of interest that will ordinarily apply to determine the interest amount included in judgments awarded under the present section will be the published Reserve Bank of Australia cash rate as at 1 January and 1 July during the claim period, plus a prescribed margin (less than that which applies to post judgment interest): see UCPR r 6.12(8) , Practice Note SC Gen 16 and DC (Civil) 15. The prescribed ordinary interest rates are set out in the table in [36.7.10]. The table reveals the higher interest rate that will ordinarily apply to interest on unpaid judgments — for periods from 1 July 2010. (For earlier periods the rates previously provided for in CPA Sch 5 apply: Lahoud v Lahoud [2011] NSWSC 994; BC201106786 at [22]–[24] .)

A party who contends that some other rate of pre-judgment interest should be awarded must support the claim with appropriate evidence: RW Miller & Co Pty Ltd v The Ship Patris [1975] 1 NSWLR 704 ; Smith v In Shoppe Pty Ltd [1976] 2 NSWLR 175 ; Hogan v Trustees of the Roman Catholic Church (No 2) [2006] NSWSC 74; BC200601061 at [37] . The choice of an appropriate interest rate will depend upon the nature of the loss claimed: see [s 100.55] and [s 100.60] . As a general proposition, and as UCPR r 6.12(8) effectively requires, the court should have regard to prevailing market rates of interest: Ruby v Marsh (1975) 132 CLR 642; 6 ALR 385 at 395 ; Legal & General Insurance Australia Ltd v Eather (1986) 6 NSWLR 390 at 409 (incorrect to adopt a merely conventional rate of interest). Hexiva Pty Ltd v Lederer (No 2) [2007] NSWSC 49; BC200700491 at [16] . An award of interest at a lesser rate can only be justified if there is good cause for so doing in the special circumstances of the particular case: see also Wallersteiner v Moir (No 2) [1975] QB 373 . These general principles are subject to any other specific statutory restrictions. Various statutory provisions restrict the rate of interest to be used in particular types of proceedings: Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18(4) (10 year benchmark bond rate); Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73 (¾ of the rate prescribed for the purposes of CPA s 101 for the period concerned); Workers Compensation Act s 151M (¾ of the rate prescribed for the purposes of CPA s 101 for the period concerned). Various statutory provisions restricting the award of interest, and the rates of interest in personal injury, insurance, motor accident and workers compensation proceedings are discussed in [s 100.55] and [s 100.60].
Legislation cited in [s 100.85] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Bills of Exchange Act 1909 s 62.

Interest cannot be awarded under the present section where a party has an independent entitlement to interest: Degmam Pty Ltd (in liq) v Wright [1983] 2 NSWLR 348 . For example, where a lease agreement provided that unpaid rent would attract 20% interest, interest was payable as of right under that provision and could not be awarded at the lesser statutory rate: Roquin Office Services Pty Ltd v Tingdale Pty Ltd [1998] ANZ ConvR 370 ; see also Bans Pty Ltd v Ling (1995) 36 NSWLR 435 ; Kelen v Vitaman Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 328; BC201002502 at [25]–[56] . Similarly s 62 of the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 (Cth) provides that damages for a dishonoured bill of exchange include interest thereon from either the time of presentation or dishonour: Dalgety v John J Hilton Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 169 . On the other hand interest is properly payable under the present section if and intended contractual provision fails because it does not nominate a particular interest rate: Brennan v Kinjella Pty Ltd (No 2) (NSWSC, Young J, 20 July 1993, unreported, BC9301835) (schedule not completed).

level.toc-caption: [s 100.90] Interest on causes of action under commonwealth legislation

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 100.90] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Judiciary Act 1903 s 79.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 94.
(SA) Supreme Court Act 1935 s 30C, s 32.

heading.title: Interest on causes of action under commonwealth legislation

p.text: A court hearing a claim based on a cause of action conferred by commonwealth legislation is exercising “federal jurisdiction” for the purposes of s 79 of the Judiciary Act 1903. The section provides that the court is bound by the laws of the relevant State or Territory.

There has been a degree of controversy about the extent to which State and Territory provisions authorising judicial awards of interest apply (i) to federal courts, by virtue of s 79 of the Judiciary Act, and (ii) to causes of action that arise under federal legislation.

Interest awards in federal courts: In Australian National Airlines Commission v Commonwealth (1975) 132 CLR 582; 6 ALR 433; 49 ALJR 338; BC7500043 , Mason J held that the terms of s 94 of the Supreme Court Act 1970 (NSW) only granted the Supreme Court power to award interest. Because the power was so limited, s 79 of the Judiciary Act did not permit the High Court (in a case it heard in Sydney) to grant interest under s 94 of the Supreme Court Act. Similar reasoning was applied in subsequent Federal Court decisions relating to s 94 of the Supreme Court Act (NSW) 1970: State Bank of NSW v Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia (1986) 67 ALR 123 ; and s 30C of the Supreme Court Act 1935 (SA): Hubbards Pty Ltd Simpson Ltd (1982) 41 ALR 509; 60 FLR 430; ATPR 40-295 . Conversely where legislation of other States conferred an interest discretion on courts generally, that discretion has been held to apply to federal courts: Centrepoint Freeholds Pty Ltd v TN Lucas Pty Ltd (1985) 6 FCR 133 at 143; 60 ALR 187 at 197 ( ss 60 and 79A of the Supreme Court Act 1958 (Vic)); Neilsen v Hempston Holdings Pty Ltd (1986) 65 ALR 302 at 311 ( s 72 of the Common Law Practice Act 1867 (Qld); Smallacombe v Lockyer Investment Co Pty Ltd (1993) 42 FCR 97; 114 ALR 568; BC9304865 ; Nellia v Kingia Pty Ltd (1985) 11 FCR 281; 61 ALR 603; ATPR 40-608 ( s 32 of the Supreme Court Act 1935 (WA)).

Interest awards on causes of action under federal legislation: In Pavich v Bobra Nominees Pty Ltd (1988) 84 ALR 285 at 293 French J held that the interest discretion conferred by s 32 of the Supreme Court Act 1935 (WA) only applied to causes of action under state law. French J held it did not apply to causes of action arising under federal law (s 82 of the Trade Practices Act 1974), and that s 79 of the Judiciary Act 1903 did not operate to enlarge the statutory interest power. Conversely, but without reference to the reasoning in Pavich v Bobra , in Truss v Brazier (1990) 96 ALR 767 at 795 the Queensland Supreme Court held that limited federal jurisdiction conferred on State courts by s 86 of the Trade Practices Act (see now s 86 of the Consumer and Competition Act 2010) implicitly contemplated the exercise of the interest discretion conferred by state legislation. In Macquarie Bank Ltd v Meinhardt (NSW) Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 15; BC201100950 at [18]–[42] Einstein J followed Truss v Brazier (although again without reference to Pavich v Bobra ) and disapproved the contrary decision in Yolarno Pty Ltd v Transglobal Capital Pty Ltd (No 4) [2003] NSWSC 1206; BC200307785 . The ultimate combined effect of these decisions is difficult to state confidently, but appears to be as follows:

where federal legislation invests state courts with jurisdiction, the terms of the federal investiture may imply a power to grant any remedies available under state law for analogous causes of action, and that possibility has been recognised in relation to claims under trade practices legislation: see Truss v Brazier, above;

if no such implication arises from the federal legislation, it is questionable whether a discretionary power to award interest under State law could properly be construed, of its own force, to apply to causes of action that arise only under federal legislation: see Pavich v Bobra, above.

An award of interest may be made against a trustee either under the present section or pursuant to the powers formerly exercised in equity, and in the latter case compound interest might be awarded. The appropriate interest rate should correspond with those normally adopted in the award of interest under the present section. There is generally no justification for using an arbitrary “trustee rate” of 4%: Hagan v Waterhouse (1991) 34 NSWLR 308 at 486; Morgan Equipment Co v Rodgers (1993) 32 NSWLR 467 at 486 . Unless the proven misconduct involves only relatively minor or technical breaches of fiduciary duty, a successful party should be entitled to compound interest: Hungerfords v Walker (1989) 171 CLR 125 at 148; 84 ALR 119 per Mason CJ and Wilson J; Schipp v Cameron (NSWSC, Einstein J, No 6425/91, 12 October 1998, unreported, BC9806860).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 101] s 101 Interest after judgment (cf Act No 52 1970, section 95; Act No 9 1973, section 85; Act No 11 1970, section 39)

leg:heading.title: Interest after judgment (cf Act No 52 1970, section 95; Act No 9 1973, section 85; Act No 11 1970, section 39)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, interest is payable on so much of the amount of a judgment (exclusive of any order for costs) as is from time to time unpaid.
Interest under subsection (1) is to be calculated, at the prescribed rate or at such other rate as the court may order, as from:
the date on which the judgment takes effect, or
such later date as the court may order.

Despite subsection (1), interest is not payable on the amount of a judgment if the amount is paid in full within 28 days after the date on which the judgment takes effect, unless the court orders to the contrary.
The court may order that interest is to be paid on any amount payable under an order for the payment of costs.
Interest under subsection (4) is to be calculated, at the prescribed rate or at such other rate as the court may order, as from:
the date or dates on which the costs concerned were paid, or
such later date as the court may order.
This section does not authorise the giving of interest on any interest payable under this section.
In this section, a reference to the prescribed rate of interest is a reference to the rate of interest prescribed by the uniform rules for the purposes of this section.
See section 136 in relation to the order in which payments on account of a judgment debt are to be appropriated.

level.toc-caption: [s 101.5] Appeal interest after judgment varied on appeal

heading.title: Appeal interest after judgment varied on appeal

p.text: Where a judgment is varied on an appeal it will ordinarily be appropriate for the judgment as varied to carry interest under the present rule from the date of judgment at first instance: Nicholson v Nicholson (1994) 35 NSWLR 308; 21 MVR 125 ; Nichol v Allyacht Spars Pty Ltd (No 2) (1988) 165 CLR 306; 81 ALR 272; BC8802664 . However, if a component of the judgment is subject to a statutory limit that has been increased since the first instance judgment, interest on the increased maximum should only be allowed from the date that the statutory increase took effect: Nicholson v Nicholson (No 2) (1995) 20 MVR 186 .
Legislation cited in [s 101.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 101(3), s 101(4), (5).

Under CPA s 101(4) and (5) interest on costs may be ordered from either the dates the costs were actually paid, or any later date specified in the costs order. These alternatives alter the previous position that interest on costs would ordinarily run from the date of the original judgment: TA Field Pty Ltd v Frigmobile of Australia Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 488 at 490 ; Hunt v RM Douglas (Roofing) Ltd [1990] 1 AC 398; [1988] 3 All ER 823 ; Thomas v Bunn [1991] 1 AC 362; [1991] 1 All ER 193 ; and Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v Carson (1994) 35 NSWLR 342 . They reflect what had previously been recognised as a discretion to award interest on costs that had been incurred and paid during the course of the proceedings: Fischer v David Syme & Co Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 606 ; Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Healy (No 2) (1991) 22 NSWLR 380 ; Hughes Bros Pty Ltd v Trustees of the Roman Catholic Church [1999] NSWSC 1051; BC9907002 (a decision based on the statutory predecessor of s 101(4) ).

The width of the s 101(4) discretion, reveals a degree of tension with the limited interest dispensation contemplated by s 101(3) (where a judgment debt is paid within 28 days). That tension is perhaps best resolved by recognising that s 101(3) does not expressly refer to the payment of costs and does not restrict the discretion conferred by s 101(4) : Woods v Woods [2001] NSWSC 1108; BC200107587 per Hamilton J. In any event, there is no requirement for special circumstances before interest may be awarded under s 101(4) : Peter Grogan (t/as P Grogan & Co) v Thiess Contractors Pty Ltd [2000] NSWSC 1101; BC200008015 at [10]–[12] .

The basic purpose of the exercise of discretion is to compensate the successful party for their prior payment of costs and disbursements related to the conduct of the proceedings: Lahoud v Lahoud [2006] NSWSC 126; BC200601167 at [82]–[83] (interest on costs awarded); applied in Drummond & Rosen Pty Ltd v Easey (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 331; BC200909763 at [4]–[5] per Macfarlan JA, Tobias JA agreeing; Evans v European Bank Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 170; BC200905581 per Basten and Campbell JJA; Ying v Song [2011] NSWSC 618; BC201104498 at [99]–[111]; North Sydney Leagues Club Ltd v Synergy Protection Agency Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 804; BC201105570 at [54] (interest on costs awarded to compensate for out of pocket costs paid) Cat Media Pty Ltd v Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd [2006] NSWSC 790; BC200606107 at [28]–[29] Bergin J; Farkas v Northcity Financial Services Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1036; BC200607961 at [10]–[13] Bergin J; Sherry v Australasian Conference Association [2006] NSWSC 1242; BC200609512 at [29]–[30] Simpson J: Woods v Woods [2001] NSWSC 1108; BC200107587 (impecunious successful party — interest obligation in relation to unpaid costs — interest on costs ordered from the date the obligation arose); see also Roads and Traffic Authority v Cremona (No 3) [2005] NSWCA 13; BC200500878 at [34] .

The court may award interest on costs even after the entry of an order for costs: Simmons v Colly Cotton Marketing Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1092; BC200708549 ; Siewa Australia Pty Ltd v Seeto Financial Services Pty Ltd (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 118; BC201000866 (judicial officer not functus officio and application incompetent — primary judge not functus officio — application for interest on costs to proceed). But if a costs order has been made by consent, and expressly provides for “no other order as to costs”, it will not ordinarily be appropriate to make a later order for the payment of interest on those costs: Lucantonio v Kleinert (Costs) [2011] NSWSC 1642; BC201203087 .

level.toc-caption: [s 101.15] Date when the judgment takes effect

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 101.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.4.

heading.title: Date when the judgment takes effect

p.text: The date when a judgment or order takes effect is determined in accordance with r 36.4 of the UCPR. If the judgment is given in court it takes effect on the date that it is made. If judgment is given otherwise than in court (eg where default judgment is entered) it takes effect on the formal entry of judgment. An order takes effect on the date that it was made. The position under the rules is, therefore, similar to the position in England: Hunt v RM Douglas (Roofing) Ltd [1990] 1 AC 398; [1988] 3 All ER 823 ; Parsons v Mather and Platt Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 715; [1977] 1 WLR 855 ; contrast RW Miller & Co Pty Ltd v The Ship Patris [1975] 1 NSWLR 704 at 723 . Accordingly, in the absence of a contrary order, interest will run from the date that any judgment or order is pronounced in court: Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v Carson (1994) 35 NSWLR 342 : but see also [s 101.30] .

level.toc-caption: [s 101.20] Foreign currency — interest rate on judgment in

heading.title: Foreign currency — interest rate on judgment in

p.text: Where judgment is given for a sum expressed in foreign currency, the court may order that interest be payable at a rate other than the prescribed rate: Nishina Trading Co Ltd v Chiyoda Fire & Marine Insurance Co Ltd [1968] 3 All ER 712 at 720; [1968] 1 WLR 1325 ; Miliangos v George Frank (Textiles) Ltd (No 2) [1977] QB 489 at 495; [1976] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 434 .
Legislation cited in [s 101.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 101(2), 101(7).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.7.

The interest rate prescribed for the purpose of CPA s 101(2) and 101(7) is set out in UCPR r 36.7 . It is the periodic cash rate published by the Reserve Bank of Australia as at 1 January and 1 July during the non-payment period, plus a prescribed margin. (The applicable rates are set out in the table at [36.7.10]).

The general considerations relevant to the selection of an appropriate interest rate are discussed in [s 100.80] . Any contractual entitlement to interest merges in the judgment and the actual judgment interest amount depends upon the present rule, rather than the contractual agreement: Ex parte Fewings (1883) 25 Ch D 338 ; Economic Life Assurance Society v Usborne [1902] AC 147 ; cf London Borough of Ealing v El Isaac [1980] 2 All ER 548 . Some statutory provisions restrict the rates of interest in insurance, motor accident and workers compensation proceedings. Those provisions are discussed in [s 100.55] and [s 100.60] .
Legislation cited in [s 101.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 101(3), s 101(5).

Ordinarily interest on the judgment amount runs from the date the judgment takes effect – subject to the prompt payment dispensation provided for in CPA s 101(3) . This general position assumes that the judgment amount has been determined. If, for example, judgment is entered for damages to be assessed, the judgment amount will be determined by reference to the loss incurred up to the date of the assessment. Where the amount of the loss has been so determined interest will ordinarily only run on that amount from the date of assessment: Thomas v Bunn [1991] 1 AC 362; [1991] 1 All ER 193 ; Kuwait Airways Corp v Iraqi Airways Co (No 2) [1995] 1 All ER 790; [1994] 1 WLR 985 . On the other hand, if the loss was complete at the judgment date and its quantification is unaffected by circumstances prevailing at the later assessment date, it will be appropriate to order interest from the judgment date. This consideration is particularly relevant to the award of interest on costs. Where the costs have been paid, or attract contractual interest, interest on costs may be ordered from the date of either payment or judgment (see CPA s 101(5) ) notwithstanding that the ultimate costs amount recoverable by the successful party may depend on the outcome of an assessment under Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004. But where interest on costs is so ordered it will also be appropriate:
to order that interest is only payable on that proportion of the total costs claimed that are sustained on the assessment, and

to order interest until payment “or further order” — in order to preserve the court’s discretion to deal with the contingency of protracted delay or misconduct in the course of the costs assessment: Lahoud v Lahoud [2006] NSWSC 126; BC200601167 at [83]–[84] .
